captions.text:
So I saw your Harry Potter and Hunger Games
sins videos.

Yeah?
Read the books, asshole!

So you’re saying that any movie based on
a book, I need to read the book first?

Yeah.
Okay, All the President’s Men. That movie’s

based on a book, and I’ve never read it,
but that movie’s awesome. You wanna know

why? Cause they explain everything. And that
movie’s entertaining. And it’s better

than Harry Potter and Hunger Games. Combined.
You’re comparing one of the most important

political stories of our time to fantasy novels?
Now, let’s just say the movie All the President’s

Men didn’t explain everything, maybe there’s
a phone call or a clandestine parking lot

meeting, but we don’t get to see it. But
all the sudden Woodward & Bernstein know all

this sh*t about Watergate but we didn’t
see how they learned it. Right, now you would

sit there and tell me to go read the book.
Well, what I’d probably say—

Or you’d say, “Don’t worry about it,
you can figure it out in five seconds if you

just think about it.” Well, sure, I can
figure out that somebody told them. Somebody

probably that worked at the White House. But
if I don’t know who it is, if I don’t

understand their
They make movies like Harry Potter for people

who read the books.
Bullsh*t. Studio guys would throw themselves

off a bridge if they made book money. Are
you telling me the only people they want to

enjoy the movie are the people who read the
book?

Filmmakers can’t put everything from the
book into the movie. Why does it matter if

Hagrid is dragging a tree. What the f*ck is
wrong with you?

I’ll tell you why. Magic. I’m watching
a movie about magic and they’re making this

poor bastard drag a giant f*cking tree all
the way across campus. Is he married to Darrin,

from Bewitched? Do they have some kind of
a gay pact--

Why does the pact have to be gay?
--to not do magic?

Look, all this is explained--
In the book? Yeah, well that’s another thing.

Why do I even care what you people who read
the book think? You people are the hardest

to please in the world. You nitpick everything.
Oh, they changed the boa constrictor to a

Burmese python! Or they didn’t do Peeves
the poltergeist! Or they left out the Sorting

Hat’s song! But if I point out one inconsistency
in the movie, you tell me “Go read the book.”

Makes everything better, right?
Well, you wouldn’t ask as many stupid questions

after.
And while we’re on the subject of magic…

is it like the Force? Do you have to believe
you have it before you actually have it? I

mean, they’re all sitting around waving
wands, doing this pseudo-Latin. If it really

comes down to who pronounces it the best,
aren’t they really just taking language

courses?
I think it’s like what Malcolm Gladwell

said. It takes, like, 10,000 hours of practice
to become a master.

Well then Hermoine should be the best wizard
in the whole series. All she ever does is

read, study, correct people, and go to the
library. She’s a better wizard than Ron.

She’s a better wizard than Harry. She’s
probably a better wizard than Dumbledore.

Dumbledore definitely has more than 10,000
hours of practice.

That’s why he does magic in one movie out
of eight.

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - Reading The Book

because it's explained in the book is like saying that they don't have the

on the viewer's lap simply to justify why the characters couldn't do 
something. ﻿

have any questions then I suppose it okay, you don't have to read the book. 
Though, I do always like to tell people to read the book bc it is better.

comments.text:
Then there are the cases where the film is completely different then the 
book. Such as:
iRobot
Jaws
World War Z
Jurassic Park
etc.

The success of films like these vary.  For some of them, the only 
correlation between the book and the movie is the title and the names of a 
few characters.
Therefore I propose that the two mediums cannot and should not be 
compared.  Instead they are two different ways that two separate artists 
interpret the same general concept. ﻿
comments.author: Richard Duryea

comments.text:
Just recently, I read the book Starship Troopers.  Then revisited the 
movie.  The two are very different especially in tone.  And yet they are 
both very good in there own way.

Hard to say which is better.  Movie had better characters and battles; 
while the novel had really interesting mythology and character struggles.  
I recommend checking out both.  "Mexican Music"

comments.text:
+Andy Boy Most books have a synopsis  On the back cover, or inside the dust 
jacket. Before I spend  $14.99 to $24.99 on a book I read that first.
comments.author: Logan Cracraft

comments.text:
+Logan Cracraft Oh, idk if you can really use that analogy for a book. A 
movie perhaps, because the trailers can be fairly telling at times, but a 
book is a mystery until it is read!
comments.author: Andy Boy

comments.text:
How does the book suck if you didn't read it? Why does it suck? I don't 
mind if you didn't like Harry Potter, and could probably find things to 
agree with you on if you could give examples of why the book/movie was bad? 
Was it cuz of character development, plot holes, actors/directors, literary 
devices, sentence structures, etc..... Yeah you have an opinion but not 
everyones opinion's worth the same, especially the perspective of the 
opinion. If its because you don't like the genre like guys who don't like 
chick flicks, then you have no opinion on the mater, not a negative one. 
I'd rather listen to someone who read/watched it and say they didn't like 
it then listen to someone who never read/watched it say why they didn't 
like. That would be a worthless 1 minute conversation. Comparing smacking 
your dick with a hammer to watching/reading a story is just a futile 
outfield analogy of not directly confronting the problem before you.
comments.author: yellind1

comments.text:
+Andy Boy
Well to use a vulgar analogy, I've never smacked my dick with a hammer but 
something tells me I wouldn't like it. I have seen roughly 60 to 90 seconds 
of "Twilight" and that's all I needed to know. In fact that was 30 to 60 
seconds more than I needed to see to know. Then there are just some things 
that do not interest me from the premise. I have been known to take 
suggestions and be pleasantly surprised.The book "Girl" by Blake Nelson for 
instance. I was only going to read it enough to say I did, and hopefully 
shut my girlfriend up, but I found that I could not put the book down. I've 
read it several times since then and it's one of my favorites. I found out 
about "The Toy Collector" by James Gunn after doing a Google search about 
Rom the Spaceknight and found out that Rom was mentioned in the book. I 
knew nothing about the story when I started reading it and it became my all 
time favorite book. On the other hand I knew the musical "Chicago" was 
gonna suck from the television ads, and I wasn't wrong. Same goes for 
"Battlefield Earth", the "Total Recall" remake, "Pink Cadillac", The 1998 
"Godzilla", Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes", and "Batman and Robin". All 
confirmed to me that they sucked after watching them.
comments.author: Logan Cracraft

comments.text: +Andy Boy I swear this is a conversation between my best friend and I lol
comments.author: greder23

comments.text:
How can you know if it sucks if you don't watch or read the material 
though? You say the book sucks, so you didn't read it and the movie sucks 
so you didn't watch it. How can you make that conclusion without having 
watched or read the material?
comments.author: Andy Boy

comments.text:
Well yeah. What is good, and what sucks is all a matter of perspective and 
taste. "Some people can read War and Peace and come away thinking it's a 
simple adventure story. Others can read the ingredients on a chewing gum 
wrapper and unlock the secrets of the universe." If I don't like it, It 
sucks. If someone else likes it, it doesn't suck to them, but they're 
opinion has no effect on me and I really don't care. If they like it, great 
just don't try to shove it in my face or I'll tell you to shove it up your 
ass.
comments.author: Logan Cracraft

comments.text:
Ah, so you just know that movies you don't watch, and books you don't read 
suck huh.

Seems legit.

comments.author: Ellen Kenny

comments.text:
Thing is though, The Lord of the Rings, Hobbit and Harry Potter films are 
made primarily for fans of the source material, so they expect their 
audiences to be familiar with the books in some way or another. Some things 
don't necessarily need explaining because we can think about it and come up 
with the answer ourselves if we haven't read the book. It's like every 
other book-based film ever, reading the book makes it better and there's 
not much reason to complain.﻿
comments.author: ManbabyPrincessScout

comments.text:
Lord of the Rings series is one that truly falls in line with the book. 
Even the cut editions went well over 2 hours and thats saying something. 
But of course if you want the full movie experience you go with the uncut. 
One of the best movie series ever made :)
comments.author: XDKX101

comments.text:
They aren't made for fans of the books, he even addresses that in video. 
 It's like he said, if Hollywood execs made book money they'd be committing 
suicide in droves.
comments.author: Hedrack1

comments.text:
+LegoJackson5
You know what they say about assumptions.  I have also read the original 
books and the appendices.  Just because the hobbit is a book made for 
children doesn't mean its a cartoon; complete with snot and fart gags, 
goofy over the top action, and a rabbit drawn sled with a wizard covered in 
bird poop and high on mushrooms.  I know Radigast the brown is a mentioned 
character in the hobbit and LODR, but a little bit of respect for the 
subject matter in his character design would have been appreciated.

I'm with you on the set designs, and some of the scenes are in no uncertain 
terms brilliant.  But for every scene that's enjoyable there are at least 
three more that leave me grinding my teeth in frustration or utterly 
disappointed.  And at the end of the day I can't give a movie a positive 
rating based on the strength of riddles in the dark with Golem alone.  So I 
have to disagree with you as to what constitutes 'a clear sign of love for 
Tolkin's books and universe as a whole.'  Because personally, (with the 
exception of one scene) i didn't see it.  In fact I got the opposite 
impression.
comments.author: Taylorwest626

comments.text:
+Taylorwest626 I'm just going to assume you haven't read the original book 
or aren't familiar with the extra material in the appendices.
I have read them and I loved it. There was actual character given to the 
dwarves, brilliant set design, mostly great effects, and a clear sign of 
love for Tolkien's books and universe as a whole. But that's just my 
opinion. You have yours, and I'll have mine. :)
comments.author: ManbabyPrincessScout

comments.text:
I'm mostly with LegoJackson on this one, every film but the hobbit was made 
primarily for fans of the books, or at the very least people who had heard 
of the books and were interested in the movie because of it.  The hobbit 
films were made to sell toys.
comments.author: Taylorwest626

comments.text:
none of those films were made primarily for the fans of the books. Actually 
its probably the opposite. The studios need to make huge profits off of the 
movies so that they can stay in business, pay the actors, directors, 
producers, etc and make more movies. So they need the average, general 
public to be interested in the movies more so than they need the smaller 
set of avid fans that actually read all the books. And I would imagine that 
most of the people who went to see the first movies in those series you 
mentioned never read the books, at least not until after they saw the 
movie.

because honestly most movie goers have not read the book. Its not fair for 
them to get a lesser story because they dont like reading﻿
comments.author: Jonathan Robinson

comments.text:
Exactly! And the vast majority of movie viewers aren't people who have read 
the books. They may come to read the books because the movie is coming out, 
or because they liked the movie; but a majority see the movie first, 
sometimes exclusively. The movies should be able to stand on their own. If 
they require a copy of the book with your ticket so you'll understand the 
plot, then you're doing it wrong.

comments.author: Filiolus

comments.text:
You sir (or ma'am) are a lot more reasonable than many others who would 
have just flamed the shit out of this video and my comment. Ultimately your 
points about the tree scene are valid. The scene's main purpose was to show 
that time had passed. It still doesn't make sense why a society that uses 
magic for the most mundane of tasks wouldn't just use magic to move a tree 
(even the beginning of The Sorcerer's Stone shows Hagrid using magic) but 
ultimately it's just a small nitpick.
comments.author: The Dashboard

comments.text:
i mean i guess...  I'm a fan of Harry Potter at least, and I'm tolerant of 
the Hunger Games.  I'm a huge fan of these guys videos because i think 
their funny and original, not necessarily because I agree with all the 
points they raise.  I don't think i'm unreasonable, I just have a different 
opinion. 

So take the Christmas tree scene.  Even at its grandest its a tiny footnote 
on the film, intended to do 3 things, 1) show a significant amount of time 
has passed,  2) show specifically its Christmas time, and 3) get a little 
more face time for the supporting facualty/staff (so they have more of a 
presence in the film, and its not just Harry, Ron, and Hermione off on 
their own somewhere).  Oh and i suppose as a possible side item, its a nod 
to the fans because this scene happened in the book.  So really 4 points to 
cover.  For what it does, its fairly effective.

The fact that magic wasn't used in transportation of the tree might be a 
sin. but it would probably be more of a sin if they spent time explaining 
why Hagrid was dragging the tree instead of using magic.  That's just poor 
time budgeting in a movie.  I mean its not like they were saying, "Hey 
harry, there's this powerful dark wizard after you.  Why? F*ck you thats 
why." then the art of tree chopping with Hagrid, then roll credits. 

So lets talk substitutes.  The only two teachers in Hogwarts who do really 
christmassy things are Hagrid and Flitwick, and both are doing christmassy 
things in the brief seconds of the Christmas montage.  Sure you can show 
Snape or Mcgonagall doing Christmas stuff, but it'll just look weird.
comments.author: Taylorwest626

comments.text: So.......was the copy of "Twilight" in the background some sort of a joke?﻿
comments.author: Hereandnow45

comments.text:
I love how Twilight's at the background..
If you pay attention.﻿
comments.author: Cherry Berry

comments.text:
I absolutely agree that a movie should be standalone.  That's why some 
books just should not be adapted to movies.  The problem with it is that 
the books get tainted because they share the same name with some shitty 
movie.  I don't think that books are a superior medium, but there are 
things that you can do, show, explain in writing that just don't adapt well 
to the screen.  You can have a far richer, more detailed, and more coherent 
story in 500 pages than you can in a 2.5 hour movie.﻿
comments.author: priceoffame

comments.text:
TL;DR - Books and movies are two different media types, with different 
strengths and weaknesses.  Some stories are not adaptable to the screen.
